boat.name: Hannah Hambleton
boat.full_description:
'Hannah Hambleton', launched in 1931, was one of the last prawners to be made by Crossfields, built on behalf of Mrs Hambleton, owner of a toffee business in Runcorn, for her grandson.

'Hannah Hambleton' was based on the Mersey for 20 years. She then fished out of Fleetwood and Millom before returning to the Wirral in 1982. De-registered for fishing in 1986, 55 years after her launch, she changed hands in 1990 and has competed in Nobby Races at Liverpool and Conway.

She has been to Brittany taking part in a traditional boat festival  and beating bigger boats, as well as to the Isle of Man.

History

1931 Built for Mrs Hambleton, owner of a toffee business in Runcorn for her grandson. Registered with fishing no. RN5. Though Runcorn was 20 miles from the mouth of the Mersey, it supported a small fishing fleet.
1951 Sold to Fleetwood. Registered as FD105
1961 Boat sold and deregistered for fishing
1966 Reregistered for fishing at Fleetwood as FD260
1974 Sold to Millom
1980 Sold to Morecambe registered as LR177
1982 Sold to Hoylake, registered for fishing as LL40 in 1984
1986 Broke adrift from her moorings in a storm and severely damaged. Rebuilt by a Birkenhead owner.
1990 Changed ownership.
boat.short_description: 'Hannah Hambleton' was built in 1931 for a member of the Runcorn Hambleton toffee family.
